I know this is probably a tough question, but do you have any tips on writing melodies? If you give me a melody, I can arrange it (figure out harmonies, bass line, drum beats etc)... but I always hear people say that melodies just 'come to them', like they just appear out of nowhere in their heads like magic... but this has never been the case for me. I usually write a chord pattern that I think sounds interesting, then I try to build a melody from the notes in the chords. Sometimes I can do it, sometimes I can't. But I know I'm doing it backwards. Melody should come first. Melody is the most important part of a song.

when writing a melody, it's sometimes hard to know 'why' you're writing the melody if there's no lyric with it. like, who cares if the notes go here or there? what's it for? what is this even about? but when you are delivering a message, through words (musical words) then all of a sudden everything has meaning. i'm not suggesting you do lyrics first, that route seems bland as hell to me. i'm suggesting you do lyric and melody at the same time. perhaps other people do it differently but that's the only way it goes for me

Why do you think certain contractions never get used by themselves? For example, you might say "I'm hungry". But if somebody asks "Hey, are you hungry?" You'd never respond by just saying "I'm" (you'd say 'I am' or 'yes' or 'no' or maybe 'I'm not'). Or you might say "I'd like to go to the movies." But if somebody asks if you want to go to the movies, you wouldn't just say "I'd".

What do you mean by "hymnifying the second half" or "fractal-like duck form"?

'hymnifying the second half' is what i sometimes call the thing in a traditional song form where the 4th 8th is the 5 chord, and the 8th 8th is the 1 chord, and the 7th 8th usually contains 1 over 5 and 5. you've heard it thousands of times. she'll be coming around the mountain, etc. Fractal like duck form is a phenomenon that occurs where the landing point of the first half is in the same relative time position as the landing point of the whole thing, relative to the whole thing. so for example, over the course of a 4 bar phrase of lyrics, let's say your first line lands halfway through the second bar, that's squarely on the 4th quarter of the first half. then your next line should have its landing point at the top of the 4th bar, which is the halfway point of the second half, and hence the start of the 4th quarter of the whole thing. so your landing point of the entire thing is in the same position relative to the whole as the landing poing of the first half was to the first half. this creates a fractal-like self-similarity that the mind responds very well to, and is present in many many lyrics/songs and rhythmic poems. (ref: duck-example-wayne.mp3)here is a simple example from lil wayne, over the course of 2 bars, where the landing point of the first half is on the 4th quarter of the first half, and then the landing point of the second half is halfway thru the second half, making it on the 4th quarter of the entire thing.

How do I know if I will be good at writing music or enjoy it if I don't have the instruments or money to buy instruments?

you're just gonna have to try some things. on one end of the spectrum, just do what feels familiar, and it may be similar to things that already existed (which is not always the biggest crime, considering 95% of music is very very similar to other music that existed before in many ways). and the opposite side of the spectrum is try things that are so outlandish that they are guaranteed to be different, even if they might be totally insane and not good. chances are you will stumble upon something good anyway. but either way it is important to try many many different things, on both sides of the spectrum, and you will very quickly learn how to fly the plane

When I write down music, I always get confused about sharps, flats and natural symbols. Like if you have a note outside of the key signature and you put a flat,sharp or natural symbol on it, (ref: q.php?date=201705232021)by the next measure are you supposed to assume that if that same note has no symbol then it's back to normal? Or if the note is altered in one clef, but not the other, do I put a sharp/flat/natural symbol on just the one clef and leave the other one unaltered?
in situations like that i think courtesy accidentals are very important
What if there's a modulation, do I put the new key signature in the middle of the score, or do I just adjust the sharps and flats accordingly?
if it stays there for a significant amount of time, then put a new key signature
My strategy is just to write everything as if it's in the key of C.

that is sometimes called an 'open key' and it is mainly used when it's just so all over the place it's not worth putting a key signature. i used an open key for a video where i transcribed and harmonized spoken language, as music. no sense putting a key because it was all over the place. but most 'reasonable' music should have a key signature

Notes that are sharp I write the sharp symbol, notes that are flat I write the flat sumbol. I never write the natural symbol, and if a note is played with a sharp or flat multiple times in the same bar, I write the symbol each time (instead of just once). This works fine for me, because usually the only per son who reads my sheet music is me. And this system makes sense to me.... but is this a bad strategy if I were to share my music with other people?Like if I were to write something out for some horn players or a piano player or whatever, would this system throw them off do you think?

yes. accidentals last at least until the end of the bar. i always thought there was disagreement about whether or not they last until the end of the line. but they definitely last at least until the end of the bar, and you should not be repeating the symbol if the note stays that way within the same bar, and therefore you need a natural to specify if it changes back. and if it changes back right at the beginning of the next bar, probably use a courtesy natural just in case. if it's in different octaves i think the rules become a little more ambiguous and courtesies are good, i'm not sure of the exact rules when it's different octaves

Hi. So the earth completes 1 rotation in 24 hours. That's 1/86400 seconds which is about 0.00001157407 Hz. Move that up a few octaves (22) and you pretty much got a G note. Using the same math... I found that Mercury and Venus are both closest to A. Earth and Mars are closest to G. Jupiter is closest to Bb. Saturn is closest to A. Uranus is closest to C#. Neptune is closest to D. So our solar system is playing, like a Gm9#11 chord? Why such a sad, weird, dissonant chord do you think? Why does our solar system feel like that? Pluto would be closest to B... which would make the chord even weirder.... I don't even know what you'd name that chord. Maybe this is why scientists don't want to make pluto a planet???

it's important to remember that those frequencies are not close enough in tune to warrant calling it the chord you called it. some of them are really like half way in between notes. i think if you are interested in what it sounds like, you will need to try putting all those frequencies together (multiplied up several octaves of course) and hear what it sounds like

I have some songs that I think can stand alone, like more traditional verse/chorus stuff with vocals... but most of my stuff is like weird little instrumental pieces, like 10 seconds to a minute in length, which I don't think would make much sense on their own (when I wrote them I had certain images in mind, like this song reminds me of a mad scientists tinkering with a bunch of test-tubes and bubbling chemicals, this song sounds like you just got "game over" in a video game, this song sounds like you just had an idea and a light bulb went off over your head, this song sounds like your taking a walk and then something crazy jumps out in front of you, this one sounds like you tried to do something epic but then failed in an anticlimactic way at the very end, etc)... sorry for this long rambling text. How come when you have 4 eighth notes in a row, sometimes there all 4 grouped together and sometimes it's written as 2 groups of 2? Is there a difference?

the rule i follow is, never beam more than 4 in a row, and don't beam across the 'imaginary barline' halfway through the bar. so if it's "1 & 2 &" beam all 4. if it's "3 & 4 &" beam all 4. if it's "2 & 3 &" beam it as 2 groups of 2 and leave the middle open. when it's the full bar, beam 2 groups of 4. for 16th notes you can apply similar rules except the 'imaginary bar line' would be between each beat, so again groups of 4 maximum, but don't beam anything across the imaginary barlines

hey, so i just heard this song on the radio, i thought it was a cover of toto's africa- it was a pretty shitty cover, but i thought someone was doing a cover of it. then when i looked it up later i found out that it was a jason derulo track called "fight for you" and it doesn't mention toto or africa anywhere on it. yet it has the same chords and even the same lyrics! it occasionally cut in some terrible pop verses but man it is actually a rip off and i wanted your thoughts on this

it is a derivative of Africa. it is authorized, and the songwriters of Africa are properly credited and paid. popular songs very often are either covers, samples, or derivatives of previous popular songs, and most of the time the original writers are credited and paid. one of the most famous examples is "surfin USA" by the beach boys, which has the entire same melody as "sweet 16" by chuck berry, who is credited and paid for "surfin USA" also. another famous example is Gansta's Paradise, which originally a Stevie Wonder song, who is credited and paid for Gangsta's Paradise as well. Another more recent example is Sam Smith's "stay with me" which was found to have nearly the same melody as "won't back down" by Tom Petty, and after an out-of-court settlement, tom petty is now credited and paid. there are hundreds more examples, and this has been common in popular music for many generations.

You answered a question recently saying that there's a circles of thirds(if I'm wrong I'm sorry) anyway, are there circles for every distance interval thing? Like is there a circle of 6ths? Circle of 4ths? 2nds? 7ths? That'd be cool if that's true.

sure, you could think of it that way. any interval when stacked will eventually get back to the same note. 4ths are just reversed 5ths, so the circle of 4ths is really the same as the circle of 5ths. 6ths and 3rds are the reverse of each other if you flip the major/minor, so everything i said about major/minor thirds would basically be true for 6ths as well if you switch the major and minor. it's just the notes will be further apart because they will be in the next octave. major seconds get back to the same note after 6 notes, it's called the whole tone scale, and it is a cliche device for a 'flashback' sort of sound. minor 2nds is just the chromatic scale, and you get back to the same note after 12. 7ths are the inverse of 2nds, again with the major/minor reversed, just like 6ths vs 3rds

is it the question mark or the fact that something is being asked make a normal sentence into a question?

in many languages and dialects (including the one you used in your question) 2 of the core words sometimes switch places when it's a question. but also an important factor is the plausibility that the thing is actually in question. additionally, if there is no question mark nor word reversal, often the presence of the word 'really/seriously/actually' can imply the question, if it is in conjunction with something that would plausibly be a question, in the context

Hello, I am interested in learning music. I know the notes and octaves and staffs and voice ranges. But I don't know what exactly a chord is. And how are they played? When do you use them? And what is the difference between flats and sharps? When are they used? If you can, please tell me. Thank you so much!

Hi Bill! I'm learning piano, and I really love that funky synth sound. But sometimes I have hard time figuring out certain chords I hear (maybe cause the notes of a chord played on a synth blend together more than a piano chord?)... But I was wondering if you can help me out with this. In this song, could you tell me the voicing for the chord that plays around the 1:44 right after 'just can't wait no more'?

that's a closed Bmin7 voicing, but it might likely have been played as Amin7 and bent up, depending on whether the player prefers to pull down the bender first and bend up to the chord, or play the chord first lower and then raise the bender. so you could play G,A,C,E, and bend it up, or pull back the bender first and play A,B,D,F# and then bend it back to center. also important to mention that this tape is also running just a hair sharp
Also those little chord hits that play around 2:44 right after 'baby I'm sure you would'? Here's the song. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LVSfnXeYmtQ

Amin6. very densely, possibly doubled in octaves, because there is definitely high A (880), but the F#(the 6 note) seems to be coming from more than an octave below. and in between you surely would have your C and E. it's just really dense and thick. also drenched in vibrato. it's Amin6, which means it includes notes A, C, E, F#. intuition tells me that this sound is automatically doubled an octave, and it's a one handed 5-note voicing with A on both ends. left hand would be working the bender/vibrato wheels

why is the circle of 5ths important? why not the circle of 3rds?
